Award.AwardTitle: IOS : Uncovering the Origins of Arthropod Body Plan Patterning
Award.AbstractNarration: The arthropods comprise the most species-rich animal phylum, filling a broad range of distinct ecological niches and comprising about 80% of all animal species. Central to the arthropods' diversity is a variety of modular, segmented body forms, as well as modular, segmented appendage forms. Features such as these are central to major animal body plans. How such features arise and diversify by the evolution of specific developmental patterning mechanisms is a fundamental issue that is not yet well understood. Water bears (tardigrades) can serve as uniquely valuable research subjects for addressing how modular, segmented body forms and appendages diversified among ancestors of the arthropods. In this project, tardigrades will be used as an outgroup to address this issue, using genomics, gene expression analysis, and reverse genetic methods. A tardigrade genome project will be completed and used to generate a publicly shared database. Diversification of body regions along the anteroposterior axis and along the proximodistal axis of the limbs will be studied using water bear gene expression and gene function studies. The project outcomes will include infrastructure for future studies of this animal phylum and will answer fundamental questions about the evolution of major animal body plans. The work will also train students and postdoctoral trainees in scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has made use of water bears, also known as tardigrades, to contribute to understanding the mechanisms by which the remarkable diversity of animal forms arose. Experiments examining key genes that control development uncovered evidence for an unexpected conclusion that the compact bodies of water bears likely arose by the loss of a large part of ancestor's bodies—a region corresponding to the entire thorax and most of the abdomen of insects. The project also resulted in the first published, draft genome sequence of a species of water bear, which will be useful for ongoing and future work on understanding how diverse animals arose. Water bears survive unusually extreme conditions including desiccation, freezing to nearly absolute zero, and exposure to the vacuum of outer space, conditions normally considered incompatible with life. For this reason, the genome sequence and methods developed and improved in this project including methods for studying gene function is expected to be valuable toward a second goal, to understand how important biomedical materials can be stored and shipped in robust forms. This project has contributed significantly to the scientific and career training of two postdoctoral fellows, three PhD students, and one undergraduate student. Contributions were made to scientific literacy through published writing about science for scientists and non-scientists, and through work with museums, high school students, and K-12 teachers.
